Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a workshop to develop an intellectual and research agenda on the topics of citizen diplomacy and citizen networks. Citizen diplomacy and citizen networks are conceptualized as a technologically mediated form of soft-diplomacy. Citizen diplomacy raises intellectual scientific challenges for researchers that are by nature interdisciplinary: technical, economic and political, and social. Technical scientific research questions concern developing new capabilities for the mobile phone for use as a primary client, novel multimodal interaction environments, the reliability of a country?s infrastructure, and using technology to create incentives to participate. Political and economic research questions include studying government policy, Internet censorship, the cost of network use, and the instability of political climates. Social and cultural research questions include dealing with illiteracy, language differences, cultural awareness, finding others to participate, developing trust in others and in technology, managing system abuse and malicious behavior, and dealing with time zone differences. There is a critical need to develop a focused research agenda that outlines the scientific and technical challenges that effectively integrates these and other research topics to benefit from the socio-technical transformations of the world wide network.

The development of technologies to support citizen diplomacy will benefit citizens of the United States as well as those in developing countries. Creating citizen networks between the developing and developed worlds will help to break down cultural, social, and political barriers. Taking such a ?bottom-up? approach with citizens may influence policy at national levels. People in both developed and developing countries will gain by learning new ideas and cultural practices. Above all, we expect that citizen diplomacy can expose young people to alternative life paths, thus limiting the impacts of local extremist views.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this two-day workshop was to build a research agenda and research community on the topic of citizen diplomacy. Citizen diplomacy combines the objectives of soft diplomacy with the use of social media to connect citizens in the developing world with the developed world. Discussion led to the following themes.

Purpose, use, and sustainability: An important factor for technologies for citizen diplomacy to succeed is that they need economic sustainability. Given the myriad of possible direct and indirect citizen diplomacy applications, different approaches are possible. Of special note are those based on freemium models where access to services are charged at different rates depending on their value with respect to basic human rights (e.g., healthcare and education vs gaming), and those that support the free software and content movement. Resources needed range from resources to create physical capital (open-source software, donated hardware, money for bulk SMS) to resources to create human capital (UN documents, HOW-TO guides, manuals).

Technological infrastructure: Technologies for citizen diplomacy need to enable fair and efficient inter-cultural communication and information sharing. As such, they need to provide access not only to reliable information sources, but also to a variety of them. Such technologies need to provide anonymity and privacy guarantees (specially for direct diplomacy activities such as conflict management). They should also consider the possibility of a moderator and should be resilient to poor IT infrastructure. Above all, they need to provide translation capabilities given the language (and cultural, and socio-economic) differences among participants.

Given the adoption rates of mobile technology and social media in both developed and developing countries, these two particular technologies present an opportunity to connect to a variety of information sources and participants.  By mining all the data produced by such mobile social networks it is possible to then identify feelings, topics, sentiments, and other relevant information that, if properly visualized, is useful to support citizen diplomacy activities such as relief efforts in crises.

Social aspects surrounding the technology: The citizen diplomacy user base is plagued with inequalities including race, age, education, access to technology, culture, language, beliefs, power, and opinions. In the best case, such inequalities thwart technology adoption; in the worst case, however, such inequalities result in misuse of citizen diplomacy technologies. Citizen diplomacy technology adoption tactics include making users aware of the networks and users they are engaging with, including their potential different cultural norms and habits. Concepts such as trust, privacy, and anonymity not only are important, but also their definition may vary among users. In the case of trust, for instance, social ergonomics can be used to generate trust with the technology and the users behind it.

Motivation is another important issue. It is of paramount importance to motivate people to participate in citizen diplomacy activities. Citizen diplomacy activities need to provide some kind of extrinsic or intrinsic value for their users. Moreover, the possibility of users adopting the technology but using it for means different than ‘citizen diplomacy’ has to be considered.

Broader impacts. We believe that this research will have a vital impact globally. To compete in the information society, people in the developing world need to possess skills to exchange information and knowledge.
